name: Button
description: Buttons allow users to take actions and make choices with a single tap. They communicate actions that users can take and are typically placed in dialogs, forms, cards, and toolbars.

overview.purpose: Buttons are the primary way users interact with your product. They should be used to trigger actions, submit forms, or navigate between pages.
principles: Buttons should clearly communicate what will happen when pressed
Use a single primary action per screen whenever possible

whenToUse: To trigger an immediate action (submit, save, delete)
To navigate to another page or open a modal
To confirm or cancel a decision
whenNotToUse: For navigation within content - use Links instead
When the action is passive or informational - use text or badges
For toggling between views - use Tabs or Segmented Controls
When space is limited and action is secondary - consider icon-only buttons

anatomy.description: A button consists of several key parts that work together to create a clear, accessible interaction.

parts.name: Container
parts.description: The outer boundary that holds all button elements and receives interaction states

parts.name: Label
parts.description: Text that describes the action. Should be concise and action-oriented

parts.name: Leading Icon
parts.description: Optional icon placed before the label to reinforce meaning

parts.name: Trailing Icon
parts.description: Optional icon placed after the label, often used for dropdown indicators

variants.name: Primary
variants.description: High-emphasis button for the main action on a screen. Use sparingly - typically one per view.
variants.useCase: Submit forms, confirm important actions, CTAs

variants.name: Secondary
variants.description: Medium-emphasis button for supporting actions that complement the primary action.

variants.name: Tertiary
variants.description: Low-emphasis button for less important actions. Often appears as text with minimal styling.
variants.useCase: Learn more links, optional actions, text-style buttons

variants.name: Destructive
variants.description: Indicates a potentially dangerous action like deletion. Uses warning colors to communicate risk.

variants.name: Ghost
variants.description: Transparent button that appears on hover. Useful in toolbars and dense UIs.
variants.useCase: Toolbar actions, icon buttons, compact interfaces

sizes.name: Large
sizes.useCase: Marketing pages, mobile-first designs, prominent CTAs

states.name: Default
states.description: The resting state of the button

states.name: Hover
states.description: Visual feedback when cursor is over the button. Slightly darker/lighter depending on variant.

states.name: Focus
states.description: Visible focus ring for keyboard navigation. Essential for accessibility.

states.name: Active/Pressed
states.description: Visual feedback during click/tap. Provides immediate response to interaction.

states.name: Disabled
states.description: Indicates the button cannot be interacted with. Reduced opacity and no pointer events.

states.name: Loading
states.description: Shows a spinner while an async action is processing. Button should be disabled during loading.

props.name: variant
props.description: The visual style of the button

props.name: loading
props.description: Shows loading spinner and disables interaction

props.name: fullWidth
props.description: Makes the button span the full width of its container

props.name: leadingIcon
props.description: Icon to display before the label

props.name: trailingIcon
props.description: Icon to display after the label

props.name: onClick
props.description: Handler called when the button is clicked

tokens.description: Design tokens used by the Button component

accessibility.description: Buttons must be accessible to all users, including those using assistive technologies.

guidelines.title: Keyboard Navigation
guidelines.description: Buttons must be focusable and activatable via keyboard (Enter or Space keys)

guidelines.title: Focus Indicators
guidelines.description: Provide clear visible focus states that meet WCAG 2.1 contrast requirements

guidelines.title: Color Contrast
guidelines.description: Button text must have at least 4.5:1 contrast ratio against the background

guidelines.title: Touch Targets
guidelines.description: Minimum touch target size of 44x44px for mobile interfaces (WCAG 2.5.5)

guidelines.title: Screen Readers
guidelines.description: Use semantic <button> element. Add aria-label for icon-only buttons

guidelines.title: Loading States
guidelines.description: Announce loading state to screen readers using aria-busy or live regions

do: Use clear, action-oriented labels ("Save changes" not "Submit")
Place primary actions on the right in button groups (for LTR languages)
Provide loading feedback for async actions
Use icons to reinforce meaning, not replace labels
Keep button labels short (1-3 words when possible)
Maintain consistent button sizing within a context
dont: Don't use multiple primary buttons on the same screen
Don't disable buttons without explaining why
Don't use vague labels like "Click here" or "OK"
Don't make buttons look like links or vice versa
Don't change button labels after interaction (except for toggles)
Don't use all caps for button labels
